20110125000958.000|20110125001000.000|TR0|planning.  Now, we can stay on the course

20110125003952.000|20110125003954.000|TR0|Arizona. And let's talk about what this 
20110125003954.000|20110125003957.000|TR0|law really includes.  What this law

20110125003959.000|20110125004001.000|TR0|allows police officers to arrest people

20110125004003.000|20110125004005.000|TR0|some point that person was suspected of 
20110125004005.000|20110125004008.000|TR0|committing a crime.

20110125004012.000|20110125004014.000|TR0|They're saying, you can arrest somebody if 
20110125004014.000|20110125004016.000|TR0|you suspect that somehow in the past, they 
20110125004016.000|20110125004018.000|TR0|were suspected.  There's a very, very low 
20110125004018.000|20110125004021.000|TR0|threshold.  It's clearly going to be found 
20110125004021.000|20110125004023.000|TR0|to be unconstitutional.  And instead of 
20110125004023.000|20110125004025.000|TR0|doing what voters sent the GOP to the 
20110125004025.000|20110125004027.000|TR0|statehouse to do, that is to create jobs,

20110125004029.000|20110125004031.000|TR0|slips for workers in Colorado, because if

20110125004034.000|20110125004036.000|TR0|Colorado what it cost Arizona, you're 
20110125004036.000|20110125004038.000|TR0|talking $150 million in lost revenue to 
20110125004038.000|20110125004040.000|TR0|the state.  That is an amazing amount of 
20110125004040.000|20110125004042.000|TR0|money at a time when the economy needs
